description: This is not a pourable sauce, but a thick, highly concentrated, and flavorful paste made from raw groundnuts. It is specifically used as a key ingredient in the ceremonial dish Luwombo. Spread over meat or mushrooms inside a banana leaf pouch, it steams and melts, creating an intensely nutty, rich, and aromatic gravy that infuses the entire dish.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: This specific preparation of groundnut is integral to the identity of Luwombo, a dish created for the Kabaka (King) of Buganda. The labor-intensive process of grinding the nuts by hand connects the cook to tradition. Its rich flavor symbolizes the importance and honor bestowed upon the guests who are served Luwombo.

ingredients.name: Raw, Shelled Groundnuts (Peanuts)
ingredients.notes: With red skins removed for a smoother paste

ingredients.name: Onion, finely grated
ingredients.notes: Adds moisture and sharpness to the paste

utensils.name: Grinding Stone (Mortar and Pestle)
utensils.notes: Traditional method for the best texture

steps.instruction: If using raw groundnuts with red skins, you can remove the skins by rubbing them between your hands or blanching them briefly. This is optional but results in a smoother, more refined paste.
Using a grinding stone (or a food processor), begin grinding the raw groundnuts. They will first turn into a coarse powder.
Continue grinding, adding a very small amount of water (a teaspoon at a time) to help the nuts release their oil and form a paste.
Grind for a long time until the paste becomes very smooth, thick, and shiny, indicating the oils have been fully released. This can take 15-20 minutes by hand.

cooking_indicators.texture: The paste should be thick, like natural peanut butter, and hold its shape.

steps.instruction: Transfer the smooth groundnut paste to a bowl. Mix in the grated onion and salt thoroughly.
The paste is now ready to be used. It should be thick enough to be spooned and spread over meat or other fillings in a banana leaf without being runny.
The bowl is now placed on top of the food in banana leaves and wrapped with two or one banana leaf and left to cook.

serving_suggestions: This paste is not served on its own. It is served with rice,matooke and other foods.
